title: Curators Are the New Creators
body:
## The Business Model of Good Taste

*This piece was originally published on [Medium](https://gabygoldberg.medium.com/curators-are-the-new-creators-the-business-model-of-good-taste-5852727d4b54) on August 23, 2020.*

* * *

**We’re experiencing a [content overload](https://blog.microfocus.com/how-much-data-is-created-on-the-internet-each-day/).** There are an average of 550 new social media users each minute, and over 40,000 search queries on Google every second. The Facebook like button has been pressed 13 trillion times, and each new day welcomes another 682 million tweets. It seems that every time we blink there’s a new podcast published, or blog post to read, or book recommendation to order on Amazon. To make a long story short, it’s becoming increasingly difficult to disaggregate signal from noise.

[Andrew Chen](https://a16z.com/author/andrew-chen/), General Partner at [Andreessen Horowitz](https://a16z.com/), wrote last year:

> “We’re living in [a pivotal time in the history of mass communication](https://a16z.com/2019/07/16/substack/) — what we believe is the golden age of new media.”

With more *creators*, more *content*, and more *choice* than ever before, consumers are now being consumed by a state of analysis paralysis. The real scarcity isn’t content anymore. It’s attention. When it’s impossible to absorb everything from the flood of information, the best we can do is pick and choose what matters to us most — or, better yet, **find the people who can do the curating for us.** [Mario Gabriele](https://twitter.com/mario_gabriele\_/status/1295031676989345792?s=20) from [The Generalist](https://www.readthegeneralist.com/) said it best:

> **“We’re all consuming more media, and** **there’s an increasing willingness to pay for high-quality content.** The last year has also seen an explosion of great writers and analysts in the space — I believe we’re at the start of a creator breakout.”

* * *

## **As the amount of content grows, so does the market for credible curators.**

A great case study is [Nathan Baschez](https://twitter.com/nbashaw) and [Dan Shipper’s](https://twitter.com/danshipper) [Everything Bundle](https://everything.substack.com/). In April, they decided to offer a bundled version of their newsletters, expecting a few extra subscribers from the experiment. Instead, they grew together from [600 to 1,000 paying subscribers](https://digiday.com/media/how-substack-has-spawned-a-new-class-of-newsletter-entrepreneurs/) within the first month. With all this talk of *unbundling* (some examples are the unbundlings of [college](https://twitter.com/eriktorenberg/status/1232193193606729728?s=20), [G Suite](https://foundationinc.co/lab/unbundling-gsuite), [Reddit](https://latecheckout.substack.com/p/the-guide-to-unbundling-reddit?utm_source=angellist), and [venture capital](https://medium.com/@marvinliao/the-slow-steady-unbundling-aka-democratization-of-venture-capital-9dcdede874af)), Nathan and Dan’s intentional *bundling* proved to be a striking success.

The Everything Bundle case study is one of my favorites, but it’s not the only one, by any means. [Channels Stack](https://www.channelsstack.com/) is a curated site for educational content on YouTube, organizing hundreds of channels into defined categories. [The Browser](https://thebrowser.com/) is a daily newsletter from someone who [reads 1,000 articles a day](https://superorganizers.substack.com/p/the-man-who-reads-1000-articles-a), choosing his five favorites and sending them out with a short summary. Oftentimes, these linked articles don’t have a paywall of their own at all — but subscribers of The Browser pay to have them sent in a curated list.

The demand is certainly there: Channels Stack launched on [Product Hunt](https://www.producthunt.com/posts/channels-stack) with a 5.0/5 average rating and nearly 400 upvotes, and The Browser has successfully figured out how to monetize free existing content (with over [40,000 followers on Twitter](https://twitter.com/TheBrowser) to boot).

We can go even further back — classic examples of successful curation businesses are record shops and [bookstores](https://pen-online.com/travel/morioka-shoten-the-book-shop-with-only-one-book/), and examples in tech include Spotify (for music), Netflix (for TV and movies), and Uber (which bundled its UberEats offering into one app, thus increasing Uber’s TAM, or total addressable market).

![](https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1\*S9v6cEdZr4ffVHV5UeVrMg.jpeg)

**In my view, however, the business of *influencer* bundling has only just begun.** Curators are the new creators, and as consumers, we’re going to be willing to pay someone with good taste to help us sort through the ever-growing mass of information at our fingertips.

* * *

## **The Psychology Behind the Need for Curation**

As it turns out, there’s some [psychological ground](https://www.ben-evans.com/benedictevans/2018/4/2/the-death-of-the-newsfeed) to all of this. Think of it as a carefully mixed cocktail of the following:

*   [Zuckerberg’s Law](https://techcrunch.com/2011/07/06/mark-zuckerberg-explains-his-law-of-social-sharing-video/), or the tendency to **share more** and more on social media over time
*   [Dunbar’s number](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dunbar%27s_number), or the average number of stable **social relationships one can maintain** at a given time (it’s around 150)
*   [Zipf’s Law](https://www.forbes.com/sites/anthonykosner/2012/05/31/facebook-values-itself-based-on-metcalfes-law-but-the-market-is-using-zipfs/#1e12bdff68f5), which describes how in any system of resources there are a **small number of items of high value**, and a “long tail” of many more of low value (slightly tangential but related reading: [Metcalfe’s Law](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metcalfe's_law), which has now [largely been refuted](https://spectrum.ieee.org/computing/networks/metcalfes-law-is-wrong) as a method of evaluating social networks, but in 2012 helped to rationalize Facebook’s insane over-valuation in its IPO)

To me, online content consumption seems to exist on a pendulum of sorts: we love content to the extreme — *Unbundle!! Give us more! —* until we are overwhelmed with choice and analysis — *It’s too much!! Bundle it back up again! —* and swing to the opposite side. In the end, we always end up somewhere in the middle… but it’s a lot of swinging back and forth on this creation/curation pendulum until we get there.

> “There are only two ways to make money in business: One is to bundle; the other is to unbundle.” — [Jim Barksdale](https://hbr.org/2014/06/how-to-succeed-in-business-by-bundling-and-unbundling)

Having said this, and looking at the current information overload we all face on a day-to-day basis, I think there’s room for a **new market of *creators as curators***. So, with that said, what does this look like for an influencer or brand?

## **How Do You Curate — and Why?**

There isn’t one sole motivation behind why creators, influencers, and brands may want to curate. In fact, curation can:

*   Build a **personal** **brand** or **audience.**
*   **Fulfill a** **need** in a particular market. For example, [Femstreet](https://femstreet.substack.com/) is a weekly digest of timely posts from female investors and operators. It’s racked up thousands of subscribers and has been featured in Fortune, Forbes, and Crunchbase.
*   Create an **extra category** within an existing business.
*   Become an additional **revenue source.** As we saw with [The Browser](https://thebrowser.com/) example, it’s possible to monetize free content if it’s curated well — consumers are willing to pay someone who has good taste, and it’s an easy way to add a revenue stream to your business.

To learn more, I asked my *own* audience about their favorite curated content:

Below is a categorized list of some of the responses I received. My favorites are in bold:

**Newsletters: **[Morning Brew](https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/signup?utm_expid=.ZTQPzZIzTFOdxoi4D0Ey0Q.1\&utm_referrer=), [**Everything Bundle**](https://everything.substack.com/)**, **[LetterDrop](https://twitter.com/letterdropio), [**Femstreet**](https://femstreet.substack.com/)**, **[Brain Pickings](https://twitter.com/brainpickings), [**The Generalist**](https://www.readthegeneralist.com/)**,** [The Browser](https://thebrowser.com/), [Snaxshot](https://twitter.com/thesnaxshot/status/1297660476671897602?s=20), [The Profile](https://readtheprofile.com/), [The Takeoff](https://thetakeoff.substack.com/), [Social Studies](https://socialstudies.news/), [Techmeme](https://www.techmeme.com/)

**Podcasts: **[Podcast Notes](https://podcastnotes.org/), [**TLDL**](https://twitter.com/TLDLdotAPP)**,** [Shuffle](https://twitter.com/getshuffleapp), [Podshots](https://podshots.substack.com/), [Podcast Review](https://podcastreview.org/)

**Crowdsourced Curation: **[Pocket](https://getpocket.com/), [**Bookshlf**](https://twitter.com/joinbookshlf)**,** [Listory](https://www.listory.com/en/), [MyHighlights](https://twitter.com/UseHighlights)

\[*Note:* there are even more responses in the Twitter thread above, in case you’re curious and want to check out more!]

## Making Curation Profitable

The best brands (and individual influencers, at that) are the best at an always-evolving curation as a service. Nathan and Dan’s Everything Bundle seems to be a playbook in itself, as outlined by [Ari Lewis](https://twitter.com/amlewis4) in [this thread](https://twitter.com/amlewis4/status/1296485567258034177):

1.  Find initial traction
2.  Shift the emphasis from the individual to the greater media brand
3.  Scale and continue to add value

One way to [monetize curation](https://www.listory.com/l/beceae7e-3c84-4595-996d-d00c4123d967?share=2e9b2a53-32fe-49cc-9186-ceadf1ca09c3) is through a paid newsletter, with the Everything Bundle as a great example. Other opportunities include blogs, ebooks, e-commerce stores, and consultations/speaking gigs. I even came across [ReadBase](https://readbase.landen.co/) during my research, which allows curators to monetize their bookmarks and reading lists. In any case, curators can find success by building up a targeted online presence and then providing curated content to that audience.

* * *

It’s clear that curating content within a particular niche can be an incredible way to build an audience and add value. Content curation hooks people in with the promise of learning new skills while saving time, and it keeps them coming back by building a sense of community around a particular subject or vertical. As outlined in this [Harvard Business Review](https://hbr.org/2014/06/how-to-succeed-in-business-by-bundling-and-unbundling) interview with Marc Andreessen and Jim Barksdale, bundling and curation can be a strategic decision for your business, as long as it’s done correctly.

Curation, in a sense, is its own form of [intertextuality](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intertextuality), or the shaping of a text’s meaning by another text. Content doesn’t exist on the Internet in a vacuum: it takes up space, and it forms a [web of influence and connections](https://laetitiaatwork.substack.com/p/emails-overload-newsletters-and-impostor). We have the content. Now, the question becomes: what will we do with it?

*   [Zipf’s Law](https://www.forbes.com/sites/anthonykosner/2012/05/31/facebook-values-itself-based-on-metcalfes-law-but-the-market-is-using-zipfs/#1e12bdff68f5), which describes how in any system of resources there are a **small number of items of high value**, and a “long tail” of many more of low value (slightly tangential but related reading: [Metcalfe’s Law](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metcalfe's_law), which has now [largely been refuted](https://spectrum.ieee.org/computing/networks/metcalfes-law-is-wrong) as a method of evaluating social networks, but in 2012 helped to rationalize Facebook’s insane over-valuation in its IPO)

To me, online content consumption seems to exist on a pendulum of sorts: we love content to the extreme — *Unbundle!! Give us more! —* until we are overwhelmed with choice and analysis — *It’s too much!! Bundle it back up again! —* and swing to the opposite side. In the end, we always end up somewhere in the middle… but it’s a lot of swinging back and forth on this creation/curation pendulum until we get there.

> “There are only two ways to make money in business: One is to bundle; the other is to unbundle.” — [Jim Barksdale](https://hbr.org/2014/06/how-to-succeed-in-business-by-bundling-and-unbundling)

Having said this, and looking at the current information overload we all face on a day-to-day basis, I think there’s room for a **new market of *creators as curators***. So, with that said, what does this look like for an influencer or brand?

## **How Do You Curate — and Why?**

There isn’t one sole motivation behind why creators, influencers, and brands may want to curate. In fact, curation can:

*   Build a **personal** **brand** or **audience.**
*   **Fulfill a** **need** in a particular market. For example, [Femstreet](https://femstreet.substack.com/) is a weekly digest of timely posts from female investors and operators. It’s racked up thousands of subscribers and has been featured in Fortune, Forbes, and Crunchbase.
*   Create an **extra category** within an existing business.
*   Become an additional **revenue source.** As we saw with [The Browser](https://thebrowser.com/) example, it’s possible to monetize free content if it’s curated well — consumers are willing to pay someone who has good taste, and it’s an easy way to add a revenue stream to your business.

To learn more, I asked my *own* audience about their favorite curated content:

Below is a categorized list of some of the responses I received. My favorites are in bold:

**Newsletters: **[Morning Brew](https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/signup?utm_expid=.ZTQPzZIzTFOdxoi4D0Ey0Q.1\&utm_referrer=), [**Everything Bundle**](https://everything.substack.com/)**, **[LetterDrop](https://twitter.com/letterdropio), [**Femstreet**](https://femstreet.substack.com/)**, **[Brain Pickings](https://twitter.com/brainpickings), [**The Generalist**](https://www.readthegeneralist.com/)**,** [The Browser](https://thebrowser.com/), [Snaxshot](https://twitter.com/thesnaxshot/status/1297660476671897602?s=20), [The Profile](https://readtheprofile.com/), [The Takeoff](https://thetakeoff.substack.com/), [Social Studies](https://socialstudies.news/), [Techmeme](https://www.techmeme.com/)

**Podcasts: **[Podcast Notes](https://podcastnotes.org/), [**TLDL**](https://twitter.com/TLDLdotAPP)**,** [Shuffle](https://twitter.com/getshuffleapp), [Podshots](https://podshots.substack.com/), [Podcast Review](https://podcastreview.org/)

**Crowdsourced Curation: **[Pocket](https://getpocket.com/), [**Bookshlf**](https://twitter.com/joinbookshlf)**,** [Listory](https://www.listory.com/en/), [MyHighlights](https://twitter.com/UseHighlights)

\[*Note:* there are even more responses in the Twitter thread above, in case you’re curious and want to check out more!]

## Making Curation Profitable

The best brands (and individual influencers, at that) are the best at an always-evolving curation as a service. Nathan and Dan’s Everything Bundle seems to be a playbook in itself, as outlined by [Ari Lewis](https://twitter.com/amlewis4) in [this thread](https://twitter.com/amlewis4/status/1296485567258034177):

1.  Find initial traction
2.  Shift the emphasis from the individual to the greater media brand
3.  Scale and continue to add value

One way to [monetize curation](https://www.listory.com/l/beceae7e-3c84-4595-996d-d00c4123d967?share=2e9b2a53-32fe-49cc-9186-ceadf1ca09c3) is through a paid newsletter, with the Everything Bundle as a great example. Other opportunities include blogs, ebooks, e-commerce stores, and consultations/speaking gigs. I even came across [ReadBase](https://readbase.landen.co/) during my research, which allows curators to monetize their bookmarks and reading lists. In any case, curators can find success by building up a targeted online presence and then providing curated content to that audience.

* * *

It’s clear that curating content within a particular niche can be an incredible way to build an audience and add value. Content curation hooks people in with the promise of learning new skills while saving time, and it keeps them coming back by building a sense of community around a particular subject or vertical. As outlined in this [Harvard Business Review](https://hbr.org/2014/06/how-to-succeed-in-business-by-bundling-and-unbundling) interview with Marc Andreessen and Jim Barksdale, bundling and curation can be a strategic decision for your business, as long as it’s done correctly.

Curation, in a sense, is its own form of [intertextuality](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intertextuality), or the shaping of a text’s meaning by another text. Content doesn’t exist on the Internet in a vacuum: it takes up space, and it forms a [web of influence and connections](https://laetitiaatwork.substack.com/p/emails-overload-newsletters-and-impostor). We have the content. Now, the question becomes: what will we do with it?

title: A portal is opening. To a world called Elektra.
body:
Once healthy and thriving, the world of *Elektra* has since turned desolate and barren. 

On *Elektra*, **music is energy**. Music is the fuel, electricity, and light of the world. 

Centuries ago, *Elektra* had a thriving civilization with a deep rooted sense of value towards art. But soon, motives around greed and self-interest took over, and the music that powered this world was lost. 

**Our mission is to travel to *Elektra*, and collectively create the music that will revive, restore and reignite this once beautiful world back to health.**

We need your help to accomplish this. [***Will you accept your mission?***](https://elektra.camp/)

## Welcome to Songcamp's second experiment — [***Songcamp Elektra.***](https://elektra.camp/)

Songcamp Elektra is a pop-up songwriting camp and production house with the intention of **co-creating a world, and owning that world together**. This full-stacked, cross-disciplinary group of artists and strategists is building an interactive experience with music at its core. 

The best part is — ***you*** are the player in this game, ***you*** are the hero of this story. 

## The Portal to Elektra opens this Monday July 12

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/caaf0c65-dc52-48db-9653-99e67cf584fd.png?height=1602&width=2880)

On **Monday July 12 at 4pm ET**, a portal will open into the world of *Elektra*. This portal will remain open for a limited amount of time. 

To access the portal, **you must secure a *Portal Ticket* NFT**. Via a contribution of ETH to the project, you will receive both your ticket *and* $ELEKTRA tokens — the currency native to *Elektra.*

You will need these tokens to complete your mission. 

**The portal opens Monday July 12 2021 at 16:00 ET. [Don’t miss it.](https://elektra.camp/)**

## The "Portal to Elektra" NFT

[Token #3953](auction://0xabEFBc9fD2F806065b4f3C237d4b59D9A97Bcac7?network=mainnet&tokenId=3953&auctionId=0x46a8efb97f9c46cee441422cb62462aa2222bbe7970430c46ea22b9c381267ce)

***Portal to Elektra*** is the first artwork coming out of Songcamp Elektra.

The visual is created in collaboration with [Metsä](https://twitter.com/madebymetsa) (3D Rendering + animation) & [Peace Node](https://twitter.com/peace_node) (flat designs), and sound design from [The Swarm](https://twitter.com/TheSwarm__). 

*The Swarm* is a team of ~10 musicians — producers, vocalists, instrumentals and engineers. They are creating the sound design, voice overs and musical soundscapes throughout the *Elektra* experience. 

The collector of this 1/1 NFT will also receive one (1) invitation to Songcamp's *Patron House* — a dedicated space for patrons to receive deep + intimate access into the growing Songcamp community and activities.

[Portal to Elektra](split://0xCDD8CB90B5585B3F0c35f5Df3a6b4fd73f52D205?network=mainnet)

More details will be revealed Monday.

See you then 🌀

→ [Elektra](https://elektra.camp/) • [Discord](https://discord.com/invite/wHsJD2sTpc) • [Twitter](https://twitter.com/songcamp_)

title: PaperclipDAO's landmark first trade... and a tribute to the NFTs that got away
body:
We just made our first trade! Paperclip DAO has swapped one $PAPER/$CLIP NFT for the [1/5 SE Earthen Concept Art Card](https://opensea.io/assets/0x76be3b62873462d2142405439777e971754e8e77/42) offered by [@bitcoinPalmer](https://twitter.com/bitcoinPalmer/status/1425273580749742081). Palmer welcome to PaperclipDAO! 🖇

We weighed several factors in making a final decision on which trade to accept. We care about more than just the economic value of a trade; we value the culture, story, and journey of the NFT as well. We also had to make a hard call about whether to honor the past or push towards the future. Our final poll after hours of discussion was a dead heat:

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/7af0279e-a154-4986-9893-743dee2c21c1.jpeg?height=756&width=1169)

It wasn’t easy, but we ultimately decided to go with a trade that highlighted the future of NFTs. 

PaperclipDAO now owns a 1/5 SE Earthen Concept Art Card, which can be used in [Parallel](https://www.parallel.life/), a sci-fi collectable game composed of digital collectible cards that can be combined into decks that dictate the game (think Magic at the Gathering or Pokemon). The Earthen Concept Art NFT was given only to early supporters of Parallel, and it's gratifying to see people taking the opportunity to recount [the NFT's unique history](https://twitter.com/GarretteDVF/status/1425657844414746629?s=20). 

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/69760d51-7aa0-4025-be9e-15367b4fee13.jpeg?height=1620&width=1080)

It’s a promising future for digitally scarce, playable cards, and since the purchase of these NFTs funds the development of the game itself, it also demonstrates the wide range of utility of NFTs. Who knows, maybe the team will let us bestow some magical paperclip power? 💫

This decision wasn’t easy; we were blown away by the offers we received and quickly realized that the hardest part would be parting with the incredible NFTs that we couldn’t accept. Check out the full [Round 1 offer thread](https://twitter.com/PaperclipDAO/status/1425117547251343369) to see all the amazing offers. 

Given the quick turnaround, we only have time to highlight a few of our favorites. In no particular order, here is our homage to the ones that got away in Round 1: 

- Our very first offer came from JPG’s [Maria Paula Fernandez](https://twitter.com/MPtherealMVP/status/1425118535857156101), who just plain got it and proposed a trade for [simulacra](https://opensea.io/assets/0x8644053aadb0df38e7734f5010fef643316bbb92/28) before we had explained the project at all. Legend. **EDIT:** There was actually a tie for the first offer, with [@AdrianLeb](https://twitter.com/adrianleb) offering a lovely [BlockArt](https://opensea.io/assets/0xb80fbf6cdb49c33dc6ae4ca11af8ac47b0b4c0f3/2544) at the exact same time as MP, making them co-legends. 
- Adam Cochran offered this [Cool Cat](https://twitter.com/adamscochran/status/1425206741084610566), complete with sunglasses and a great story. As competition heated up, he increased the offer to [4 Cool Cats](https://twitter.com/adamscochran/status/1425249645253496832). Adam later put forth an offer that absolutely blew his first two away! [He proposed a collection of 14 historic NFTs](https://twitter.com/adamscochran/status/1425487421895057408), in a collection titled Moments in Our History. This collection represents unique fists, influential artists, and rare defunct collectibles that helped shape the NFT space and have led to the NFT renaissance we're living right now. It’s an excellent read.
- [A $HASH of the @paperclipDAO UNIv3 NFT](https://twitter.com/blasteasy/status/1425181303767543815) was also minted and proposed. Proof of Beauty is stunning. Just look at them. And to honor our project with a mint of the $PAPER/$CLIP NFT floored us. [Sisyphus](https://twitter.com/0xSisyphus) also offered [an original Proof of Beauty](https://opensea.io/assets/0xe18a32192ed95b0fe9d70d19e5025f103475d7ba/57896044618658097711785492504343953927315557066662158946655541218820101244980), for Beeple's first Everydays mint on-chain in another historic NFT moment offered for the first trade. 

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/826bf6cf-b6d7-420c-bade-3d6420592cfa.jpeg?height=1800&width=1125)

- [MoonCatRescue](https://mooncatrescue.com/) is absolutely one of the great NFT stories, with a community rediscovering and rescuing these Mooncats that have been “trapped” since the project began in 2017 (!!!). No way to do it justice here--[you have to read about it](https://mooncatrescue.com/). We were lucky to be offered several Mooncats ([this one](https://opensea.io/assets/0xc3f733ca98e0dad0386979eb96fb1722a1a05e69/1549), [this one](https://opensea.io/assets/0x7c40c393dc0f283f318791d746d894ddd3693572/2223), and [this one](https://opensea.io/assets/0xc3f733ca98e0dad0386979eb96fb1722a1a05e69/18995)). 
- [Folia](https://twitter.com/foliafoliafolia/status/1425172915889266693)’s Kudzu virus is the genius brainchild of Billy Rennekamp, one of the NFT OG’s ([with the NFT to prove it](https://opensea.io/assets/0x72148fcae1d77eebcd9486af7e656bb736c213ef/3?embed=night)). There’s nothing else like it--it’s a permanent NFT that will never leave your wallet. When you send it to someone it mutates and they get their own, permanent, NFT. We were offered 2 ([this one](https://twitter.com/foliafoliafolia/status/1425172915889266693) and [this one](https://opensea.io/assets/0xdce09254dd3592381b6a5b7a848b29890b656e01/2000062)).
- [Calvin Liu](https://twitter.com/cjliu49/status/1425235759934541829) offered up a [Non-fungible Pepe](https://sudoswap.xyz/#/swap/N4Igtghg1gpgTgQQM5JgFwCITREAuEABgA8BOAFgGMAzSgEzoHZCXW32POvufPzeBgoYIAcw8RPEBGSbLkcZ8pbMXK1ggEzrtA8vw0BWRlMakty6lNJjyANhh0Dt8hEKUYtxiIMwARgeoqGC0DSl8RK3IYamCdOM4AZhh4nRAAGnBoeGRUNAQwAHsAVwA7NHwQKXSQHFhEFHQsHAqSChp6JhSuwn5ulLE%2BlNVB7WGRtTHx%2BXMptT1CQ2NTGflKBOdyDV8XcgMNDRgRYwTSUnoliF8GEXJGS6kpGJEB2ZUzOltXiWra7Ia8wqlcoEKoZGDEAAOAEs4NgoQUSgAVKFgGAAZRglARdCQFXWWj0GlICQS1UgdQQDDgMBQLWIGjoDI0EEepF81DorkZ63I20cJmoIlsBz2MVoGmYpIyv0QVJpuIIJC%2B1RiMAASpiodCYGVKXRqbTFcQohpqNZKKR7AyDKQDBARAkEAAxCAJAzPEQAYRc1HdCDW5ASAFE9NVUCU6Nk5YaiMRlRlyfAnTAYC0flk4MnU4qwxAADbAyrCoUJRgGAxSG0GargygACwgJQA5jA9QaFbHCGJ2RXCE7Pb4nVIRL5SA9CAZboRbCcYLbbDJ9sTGMYNGGoU2StgitS6VJKLYK8t1lITncqCIzRBqIxenRAi5nJQpBAx7dI7ZqNQtqFCMw6KeE6UNOZa2j0Cy%2BPuviML4-hPIwn68nc37kKeAQJAsl5mDB%2By3L4NAUPckF0BOviEA4EAQFQvgJFopIAL5AA), which was a close contender (see final poll above). Creator Matt Furie is well known for creating Pepe the Frog back in 2005 for a comic called “Boys Club,” which subsequently went on to become the Internet meme that we all know and love. 
- [@JordanLzG](https://twitter.com/JordanLzG/status/1425259957658824709) splashed the pot by offering [The Title Open Edition by Pak](https://niftygateway.com/collections/pakopen). Pak is an anonymous creator at the forefront of experience-based art. His work was recently auctioned by Sotheby’s and his collection The Title (from which The Cheap hails) was one of the best NFT-based experiences in 2020. We were also offered 3 in Pak’s [The Flipper](https://opensea.io/assets/0x090c53bac270768759c8f4c93151bd1a808a280e/18700020009) series.
- In a very special offer, [devops199fan](https://twitter.com/cjliu49/status/1425235759934541829) offered [#404/420 of the EthereumFilm Infinite Garden Bloom NFT](https://twitter.com/devops199fan/status/1425257222364295174) in collaboration with the one and only [pplpleasr](https://twitter.com/pplpleasr1) 🤩 . Each NFT is tied to select on-screen credits in the film, which will be the first feature-length Ethereum documentary and the first documentary funded via NFTs. 
- [Astrocryptids](https://twitter.com/CoffeeTimesTW/status/1425254256563482627?s=20) is a charming little project where a twitter transmission bot “beams” mysterious code to an artist who then creates algorithmic sprites with a unique star code. [We were offered 7](https://twitter.com/CoffeeTimesTW/status/1425293234381541381). 
- Artblocks is the premier name in abstract NFT art, and among several Artblocks curated pieces we were offered was a gorgeous [Rinascita](https://artblocks.io/token/121000845).
- [Jonathan Mann](https://twitter.com/songadaymann/status/1425431457053487104), the [songadaymann](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5dgSLSe4qsY) himself, wrote us a song about the man that did/didn’t invent the paperclip! This ranked the highest in paperclip-iness! Truly the one that got away. He’s since started [an auction for the song](https://twitter.com/songadaymann/status/1425773677581324296?s=21) on Zora.
- For the real OGs, we were offered a very rare [5x symmetrical clover](https://opensea.io/assets/0xb55c5cac5014c662fdbf21a2c59cd45403c482fd/226854885927226686664340372062743472810) (from Clovers.Network) of which only 55 were ever found. It has symmetry in both diagonals, x & y axes, and rotationally. It’s also a very lucky four leaf clover! 
- We were offered a [Pudgy Penguin](https://opensea.io/assets/0xbd3531da5cf5857e7cfaa92426877b022e612cf8/2581), [a Meebit](https://opensea.io/assets/0x7bd29408f11d2bfc23c34f18275bbf23bb716bc7/10204), and a [baby Bored Ape](https://opensea.io/assets/0x495f947276749ce646f68ac8c248420045cb7b5e/56725515187736557735990102071773169311374405330094350701016781023838914740225) - a nod to the many emerging icons of the NFT world.      
One interesting offer included all three NFT standards: an ERC-20 ([an $XMON](https://etherscan.io/token/0x3aada3e213abf8529606924d8d1c55cbdc70bf74)), ERC-721 ([an Artblocks](https://opensea.io/assets/0xa7d8d9ef8d8ce8992df33d8b8cf4aebabd5bd270/44000143)), and ERC-1155 ([a Parallel](https://opensea.io/assets/0x76be3b62873462d2142405439777e971754e8e77/10247)) 
- [Pixel Portraits](https://twitter.com/thepxlportraits) is a fun project with portraits of interesting people in the cryptopunks style. NFT legend Nick Johnson offered his portrait of [Alan Turing](https://opensea.io/assets/0x495f947276749ce646f68ac8c248420045cb7b5e/8112316025873927737505937898915153732580103913704334048512380170839124869121).
- Finally, we were [given a choice](https://twitter.com/paperclipDAO/status/1425117547251343369) between 1.) a rare 1/27 [XCOPY piece](https://opensea.io/assets/0x580a29fa60b86aaff102743de5cba60bb5f9de75/329) from an obscure NFT project launched in 2018 or 2.) a 0xmons named [Maznoth](https://opensea.io/assets/0x0427743df720801825a5c82e0582b1e915e0f750/233) + [their unique sound](https://opensea.io/assets/0x83b28b0a2d44f48ea81d9da535a5ccb74ef71a05/233). 

Each of these offers makes our story all the richer and we couldn’t be more excited about our first trade. In Round 1, we picked the future. But the past always has a way of coming back... Round 2 starts now! 🖇🖇

- [Pixel Portraits](https://twitter.com/thepxlportraits) is a fun project with portraits of interesting people in the cryptopunks style. NFT legend Nick Johnson offered his portrait of [Alan Turing](https://opensea.io/assets/0x495f947276749ce646f68ac8c248420045cb7b5e/8112316025873927737505937898915153732580103913704334048512380170839124869121).
- Finally, we were [given a choice](https://twitter.com/paperclipDAO/status/1425117547251343369) between 1.) a rare 1/27 [XCOPY piece](https://opensea.io/assets/0x580a29fa60b86aaff102743de5cba60bb5f9de75/329) from an obscure NFT project launched in 2018 or 2.) a 0xmons named [Maznoth](https://opensea.io/assets/0x0427743df720801825a5c82e0582b1e915e0f750/233) + [their unique sound](https://opensea.io/assets/0x83b28b0a2d44f48ea81d9da535a5ccb74ef71a05/233).

Paperclip DAO has swapped one $PAPER/$CLIP NFT for the [1/5 SE Earthen Concept Art Card](https://opensea.io/assets/0x76be3b62873462d2142405439777e971754e8e77/42) offered by [@bitcoinPalmer](https://twitter.com/bitcoinPalmer/status/1425273580749742081). Palmer welcome to PaperclipDAO! 🖇

We weighed several factors in making a final decision on which trade to accept. We care about more than just the economic value of a trade; we value the culture, story, and journey of the NFT as well. We also had to make a hard call about whether to honor the past or push towards the future. Our final poll after hours of discussion was a dead heat:

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/7af0279e-a154-4986-9893-743dee2c21c1.jpeg?height=756&width=1169)

It wasn’t easy, but we ultimately decided to go with a trade that highlighted the future of NFTs. 

PaperclipDAO now owns a 1/5 SE Earthen Concept Art Card, which can be used in [Parallel](https://www.parallel.life/), a sci-fi collectable game composed of digital collectible cards that can be combined into decks that dictate the game (think Magic at the Gathering or Pokemon). The Earthen Concept Art NFT was given only to early supporters of Parallel, and it's gratifying to see people taking the opportunity to recount [the NFT's unique history](https://twitter.com/GarretteDVF/status/1425657844414746629?s=20). 

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/69760d51-7aa0-4025-be9e-15367b4fee13.jpeg?height=1620&width=1080)

It’s a promising future for digitally scarce, playable cards, and since the purchase of these NFTs funds the development of the game itself, it also demonstrates the wide range of utility of NFTs. Who knows, maybe the team will let us bestow some magical paperclip power? 💫

This decision wasn’t easy; we were blown away by the offers we received and quickly realized that the hardest part would be parting with the incredible NFTs that we couldn’t accept. Check out the full [Round 1 offer thread](https://twitter.com/PaperclipDAO/status/1425117547251343369) to see all the amazing offers. 

Given the quick turnaround, we only have time to highlight a few of our favorites. In no particular order, here is our homage to the ones that got away in Round 1: 

- Our very first offer came from JPG’s [Maria Paula Fernandez](https://twitter.com/MPtherealMVP/status/1425118535857156101), who just plain got it and proposed a trade for [simulacra](https://opensea.io/assets/0x8644053aadb0df38e7734f5010fef643316bbb92/28) before we had explained the project at all. Legend. **EDIT:** There was actually a tie for the first offer, with [@AdrianLeb](https://twitter.com/adrianleb) offering a lovely [BlockArt](https://opensea.io/assets/0xb80fbf6cdb49c33dc6ae4ca11af8ac47b0b4c0f3/2544) at the exact same time as MP, making them co-legends. 
- Adam Cochran offered this [Cool Cat](https://twitter.com/adamscochran/status/1425206741084610566), complete with sunglasses and a great story. As competition heated up, he increased the offer to [4 Cool Cats](https://twitter.com/adamscochran/status/1425249645253496832). Adam later put forth an offer that absolutely blew his first two away! [He proposed a collection of 14 historic NFTs](https://twitter.com/adamscochran/status/1425487421895057408), in a collection titled Moments in Our History. This collection represents unique fists, influential artists, and rare defunct collectibles that helped shape the NFT space and have led to the NFT renaissance we're living right now. It’s an excellent read.
- [A $HASH of the @paperclipDAO UNIv3 NFT](https://twitter.com/blasteasy/status/1425181303767543815) was also minted and proposed. Proof of Beauty is stunning. Just look at them. And to honor our project with a mint of the $PAPER/$CLIP NFT floored us. [Sisyphus](https://twitter.com/0xSisyphus) also offered [an original Proof of Beauty](https://opensea.io/assets/0xe18a32192ed95b0fe9d70d19e5025f103475d7ba/57896044618658097711785492504343953927315557066662158946655541218820101244980), for Beeple's first Everydays mint on-chain in another historic NFT moment offered for the first trade. 

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/826bf6cf-b6d7-420c-bade-3d6420592cfa.jpeg?height=1800&width=1125)

- [MoonCatRescue](https://mooncatrescue.com/) is absolutely one of the great NFT stories, with a community rediscovering and rescuing these Mooncats that have been “trapped” since the project began in 2017 (!!!). No way to do it justice here--[you have to read about it](https://mooncatrescue.com/). We were lucky to be offered several Mooncats ([this one](https://opensea.io/assets/0xc3f733ca98e0dad0386979eb96fb1722a1a05e69/1549), [this one](https://opensea.io/assets/0x7c40c393dc0f283f318791d746d894ddd3693572/2223), and [this one](https://opensea.io/assets/0xc3f733ca98e0dad0386979eb96fb1722a1a05e69/18995)). 
- [Folia](https://twitter.com/foliafoliafolia/status/1425172915889266693)’s Kudzu virus is the genius brainchild of Billy Rennekamp, one of the NFT OG’s ([with the NFT to prove it](https://opensea.io/assets/0x72148fcae1d77eebcd9486af7e656bb736c213ef/3?embed=night)). There’s nothing else like it--it’s a permanent NFT that will never leave your wallet. When you send it to someone it mutates and they get their own, permanent, NFT. We were offered 2 ([this one](https://twitter.com/foliafoliafolia/status/1425172915889266693) and [this one](https://opensea.io/assets/0xdce09254dd3592381b6a5b7a848b29890b656e01/2000062)).
- [Calvin Liu](https://twitter.com/cjliu49/status/1425235759934541829) offered up a [Non-fungible Pepe](https://sudoswap.xyz/#/swap/N4Igtghg1gpgTgQQM5JgFwCITREAuEABgA8BOAFgGMAzSgEzoHZCXW32POvufPzeBgoYIAcw8RPEBGSbLkcZ8pbMXK1ggEzrtA8vw0BWRlMakty6lNJjyANhh0Dt8hEKUYtxiIMwARgeoqGC0DSl8RK3IYamCdOM4AZhh4nRAAGnBoeGRUNAQwAHsAVwA7NHwQKXSQHFhEFHQsHAqSChp6JhSuwn5ulLE%2BlNVB7WGRtTHx%2BXMptT1CQ2NTGflKBOdyDV8XcgMNDRgRYwTSUnoliF8GEXJGS6kpGJEB2ZUzOltXiWra7Ia8wqlcoEKoZGDEAAOAEs4NgoQUSgAVKFgGAAZRglARdCQFXWWj0GlICQS1UgdQQDDgMBQLWIGjoDI0EEepF81DorkZ63I20cJmoIlsBz2MVoGmYpIyv0QVJpuIIJC%2B1RiMAASpiodCYGVKXRqbTFcQohpqNZKKR7AyDKQDBARAkEAAxCAJAzPEQAYRc1HdCDW5ASAFE9NVUCU6Nk5YaiMRlRlyfAnTAYC0flk4MnU4qwxAADbAyrCoUJRgGAxSG0GargygACwgJQA5jA9QaFbHCGJ2RXCE7Pb4nVIRL5SA9CAZboRbCcYLbbDJ9sTGMYNGGoU2StgitS6VJKLYK8t1lITncqCIzRBqIxenRAi5nJQpBAx7dI7ZqNQtqFCMw6KeE6UNOZa2j0Cy%2BPuviML4-hPIwn68nc37kKeAQJAsl5mDB%2By3L4NAUPckF0BOviEA4EAQFQvgJFopIAL5AA), which was a close contender (see final poll above). Creator Matt Furie is well known for creating Pepe the Frog back in 2005 for a comic called “Boys Club,” which subsequently went on to become the Internet meme that we all know and love. 
- [@JordanLzG](https://twitter.com/JordanLzG/status/1425259957658824709) splashed the pot by offering [The Title Open Edition by Pak](https://niftygateway.com/collections/pakopen). Pak is an anonymous creator at the forefront of experience-based art. His work was recently auctioned by Sotheby’s and his collection The Title (from which The Cheap hails) was one of the best NFT-based experiences in 2020. We were also offered 3 in Pak’s [The Flipper](https://opensea.io/assets/0x090c53bac270768759c8f4c93151bd1a808a280e/18700020009) series.
- In a very special offer, [devops199fan](https://twitter.com/cjliu49/status/1425235759934541829) offered [#404/420 of the EthereumFilm Infinite Garden Bloom NFT](https://twitter.com/devops199fan/status/1425257222364295174) in collaboration with the one and only [pplpleasr](https://twitter.com/pplpleasr1) 🤩 . Each NFT is tied to select on-screen credits in the film, which will be the first feature-length Ethereum documentary and the first documentary funded via NFTs. 
- [Astrocryptids](https://twitter.com/CoffeeTimesTW/status/1425254256563482627?s=20) is a charming little project where a twitter transmission bot “beams” mysterious code to an artist who then creates algorithmic sprites with a unique star code. [We were offered 7](https://twitter.com/CoffeeTimesTW/status/1425293234381541381). 
- Artblocks is the premier name in abstract NFT art, and among several Artblocks curated pieces we were offered was a gorgeous [Rinascita](https://artblocks.io/token/121000845).
- [Jonathan Mann](https://twitter.com/songadaymann/status/1425431457053487104), the [songadaymann](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5dgSLSe4qsY) himself, wrote us a song about the man that did/didn’t invent the paperclip! This ranked the highest in paperclip-iness! Truly the one that got away. He’s since started [an auction for the song](https://twitter.com/songadaymann/status/1425773677581324296?s=21) on Zora.
- For the real OGs, we were offered a very rare [5x symmetrical clover](https://opensea.io/assets/0xb55c5cac5014c662fdbf21a2c59cd45403c482fd/226854885927226686664340372062743472810) (from Clovers.Network) of which only 55 were ever found. It has symmetry in both diagonals, x & y axes, and rotationally. It’s also a very lucky four leaf clover! 
- We were offered a [Pudgy Penguin](https://opensea.io/assets/0xbd3531da5cf5857e7cfaa92426877b022e612cf8/2581), [a Meebit](https://opensea.io/assets/0x7bd29408f11d2bfc23c34f18275bbf23bb716bc7/10204), and a [baby Bored Ape](https://opensea.io/assets/0x495f947276749ce646f68ac8c248420045cb7b5e/56725515187736557735990102071773169311374405330094350701016781023838914740225) - a nod to the many emerging icons of the NFT world.      
One interesting offer included all three NFT standards: an ERC-20 ([an $XMON](https://etherscan.io/token/0x3aada3e213abf8529606924d8d1c55cbdc70bf74)), ERC-721 ([an Artblocks](https://opensea.io/assets/0xa7d8d9ef8d8ce8992df33d8b8cf4aebabd5bd270/44000143)), and ERC-1155 ([a Parallel](https://opensea.io/assets/0x76be3b62873462d2142405439777e971754e8e77/10247)) 
- [Pixel Portraits](https://twitter.com/thepxlportraits) is a fun project with portraits of interesting people in the cryptopunks style. NFT legend Nick Johnson offered his portrait of [Alan Turing](https://opensea.io/assets/0x495f947276749ce646f68ac8c248420045cb7b5e/8112316025873927737505937898915153732580103913704334048512380170839124869121).
- Finally, we were [given a choice](https://twitter.com/paperclipDAO/status/1425117547251343369) between 1.) a rare 1/27 [XCOPY piece](https://opensea.io/assets/0x580a29fa60b86aaff102743de5cba60bb5f9de75/329) from an obscure NFT project launched in 2018 or 2.) a 0xmons named [Maznoth](https://opensea.io/assets/0x0427743df720801825a5c82e0582b1e915e0f750/233) + [their unique sound](https://opensea.io/assets/0x83b28b0a2d44f48ea81d9da535a5ccb74ef71a05/233). 

Each of these offers makes our story all the richer and we couldn’t be more excited about our first trade. In Round 1, we picked the future. But the past always has a way of coming back... Round 2 starts now! 🖇🖇

title: A beginner's guide to NFTs
body:
#### What are NFTs?

Non-fungible token (NFT) is a term used to describe a unique digital asset whose ownership is tracked on a blockchain, such as Ethereum. Assets that can be represented as NFTs range from digital goods, such as items that exist within virtual worlds, to claims on physical assets such as clothing items or real estate. In the coming years, we will see NFTs used to unlock entirely new use cases that are only made possible by crypto.

 ![Test caption](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/9799dae1-c2c9-4712-813b-10b23c279a36.jpeg)

While the Ethereum ecosystem is where most NFT activity has taken place to date, NFTs can exist on other smart contract platforms too. This is because, at their core, NFTs are just digital abstractions used to represent assets that are one of a kind. Non-fungible token isn’t the most intuitive term since we don’t commonly refer to the fungibility of objects in the physical world, but this is an important technical distinction when it comes to how an asset is represented on a blockchain. The goal for this post is not to detail every project within the NFT space, but to give a high level overview of what NFTs are, why they are interesting, and showcase some of their potential use cases.

#### Why are NFTs interesting?

NFTs are powerful because, when combined with other financial building blocks on Ethereum, they allow anyone to issue, own, and trade them. This makes interacting with NFTs significantly more efficient than in traditional platforms. The same reason why cryptocurrency used in payments is more efficient than traditional payments, that it is borderless and significantly easier to transfer, applies to NFTs. For example, if you want to create tradable in-game items as a game developer, then you can instantly have them be tradable through protocols that allow for decentralized exchange of NFTs. You don’t have to create your own marketplace or go through the onboarding process of a centralized platform in order to have the items be tradable.

NFT activity can go well past trading and include actions like being able to borrow and lend, support fractional ownership (e.g. [NIFTEX](https://www.niftex.com/)), or use it as collateral in taking out a loan (e.g. [NFTfi](https://nftfi.com/)). The possibilities are endless when you have the ability to combine NFTs with DeFi building blocks. For example, the game [Aavegotchi](http://aavegotchi.com) combines DeFi and NFT gaming where each Aavegotchi character represents a user’s collateral that is deposited within the lending platform [Aave](https://aave.com/), but you can also battle the characters, level them up, and equip wearables that change their traits.

\
 ![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/a1259686-6b61-455a-a204-f6e6da648f10.jpeg)

\
NFTs can cover an extremely wide variety of areas given they are simply digital representations of ownership but there has been significant growth within art and gaming in particular. Note that many digital works of art and gaming items are a subset of a larger category of NFT collectibles. There is also the emerging space of social tokens, which sometimes falls into the NFT category or that is closely related to it.

#### Art

NFTs can make fractionalized ownership more accessible, so if there is a valuable item that otherwise wouldn’t have been accessible for someone to own, now they can own a piece of it. Custody of a physical item still requires a trustworthy custodian, but being able to issue, hold, and trade it as a cryptoasset unlocks more use cases. One can also craft an NFT such that the creator receives a percentage of all secondary sales in a completely automated way. Artists typically don’t receive a cut of secondary sales in the traditional art world.

Programmable art is another interesting concept where a piece of artwork can incorporate on-chain data to dynamically update certain features or characteristics of the work. For example, one could create a piece of programmable art whose background changes if the price of ether goes above a certain dollar-value. There are countless creative possibilities.

\
 ![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/a51670c0-4a1c-4aaf-917d-0e551855b56d.jpeg)

\
[Async Art](https://async.art/) is a digital art marketplace known for programmable art. Many artists on Async sell artwork where someone is able to own the “master” copy which consists of a number of individual layers, but other people can own the individual layers and adjust their attributes over time. Imagine groups of people being able to own art collectively, where members of the group manage attributes of the work.

\
 ![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/fea07c75-8b3c-4592-b8f2-f5d6d92e544c.jpeg)

\
A common question about digital artwork is what can you do with it? These works can be displayed in digital frames in a physical setting for people to enjoy. The digital artist Beeple sold physical tokens along with his digital NFTs and made [$3.5 million](https://niftygateway.com/itemdetail/primary/0x6e5dc5405baefb8c0166bcc78d2692777f2cbffb/21) from sales in an auction on the Nifty Gateway marketplace.

\
 ![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/8689be31-b33f-46ac-94aa-feea3a1b3dd1.jpeg)

\
Digital artwork can also be displayed in online collections like a [SuperRare profile](https://superrare.co/thevault/collection) as well as in virtual worlds. There are a number of art galleries within [Cryptovoxels](http://cryptovoxels.com), a virtual world where users can buy and sell land parcels as NFTs. As virtual reality spaces become more popular, having digital art to display will become more common. This wouldn’t be much different than someone spending money on video game items to customize a character’s appearance, already a multi-billion dollar industry.

\
 ![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/7386d358-d43d-4934-9ea5-b51c33932365.jpeg)

\
A common skepticism is that someone can just take a screenshot of the image or get a digital file so it’s not really scarce. However, the same argument could apply to physical items as well. Anyone can take a photo of the Mona Lisa or create a replica of it, but it isn’t the real item from the artist. People are willing to pay a premium for the original work. Another interesting aspect of digital art or collectibles is that you can easily verify the item’s ownership history. Some digital items might be worth more depending on who owned it in the past.

With NFTs, you can also prove that the item is real and tamper proof. This is an issue in the physical collectibles space. For example, a [T206 Honus Wagner baseball card](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/T206_Honus_Wagner) was sold to Wayne Gretzky for $451k and sold again for several million dollars. One of the sellers of the card later admitted in court to trimming the card’s edges to make it look better. You can ensure NFT supply doesn’t change and there’s no counterfeit or continued printing. For example, there are many [counterfeit Black Lotus](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AAvLC3fz068&) cards in the popular game Magic: The Gathering. Common verification methods include bending the card to make sure it doesn’t crease or going through centralized grading services whose rating significantly affects the card's value.

#### Gaming

Steam, a popular video game platform, has a [Community Market](https://steamcommunity.com/market/?) where in-game items can be bought and sold. Steam’s marketplace is centralized and collects a transaction fee of 5% for each item from the buyer. Games like Team Fortress 2 and Dota 2 take an additional fee of 10% for their items sold.

\
 ![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/4ad85fcf-b986-4b60-9fb5-925200fde3a9.jpeg)

\
Steam also restricts user wallet balances to $2,000 and the price of a single item to $1,800. While these cases are outliers, many in-game items can actually sell for significantly larger amounts such as the [DotA 2 pink war dog courier](https://www.engadget.com/2013-11-06-dota-2-pink-war-dog-courier-sells-for-38-000.html) for $38,000. Within the crypto space there have also been high priced sales such as the $170,000 [CryptoKitty](https://thenextweb.com/hardfork/2018/09/05/most-expensive-cryptokitty/). Similarly Magic: The Gathering’s coveted [Black Lotus](https://www.polygon.com/2019/3/5/18251623/magic-the-gathering-black-lotus-auction-price) card sold for $166,100. There is certainly demand for valuable in-game items. In decentralized marketplaces, there isn’t a limit imposed on what game items can be sold and for what amount.

Decentralized marketplaces can significantly reduce transaction fees due to the improved efficiency of starting up and operating a marketplace. Marketplaces can also improve overall user experience and increase interest in the game. Hearthstone is a wildly popular digital collectible card game created by Blizzard Entertainment that had over [100 million players](https://variety.com/2018/gaming/news/hearthstone-has-over-100-million-players-1203019919/) in 2018. Hearthstone opted to not have a marketplace for their cards which leaves opportunity for other digital collectible card games that allow for an open marketplace. [Gods Unchained](https://godsunchained.com/) and [SkyWeaver](https://www.skyweaver.net/) are two trading card games (TCGs) that have cards that are freely tradable. You are also able to earn cards as you level up in the game. Players that did not purchase packs of cards will still be able to improve upon the game’s default decks. It’s an exciting feeling knowing that the earned cards have real world value and can be sold or traded for other cards. Gods Unchained also lets users earn tokens for when they win a match or refer their friend. The tokens themselves unlock rare in-game items and are also freely tradable.

\
 ![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/aa82c586-39b6-46b1-ae55-cb8a2e44c8e1.jpeg)

\
One of the most popular games in crypto is [Axie Infinity](https://axieinfinity.com/). You battle with a team of pet Axies and level them up. There's no aspect of the gameplay that feels like a blockchain game but there is the added benefit of being able to openly trade the Axies on NFT marketplaces such as [OpenSea](https://opensea.io/). The game has become popular in the [Philippines](https://www.coindesk.com/nft-game-filipinos-covid) and earning tokens from the game has become a viable source of income for players even [beating minimum wage](https://www.playtoearn.online/2020/07/08/axie-infinity-beats-minimum-wage-in-many-countries/) in many countries. There is also a decentralized autonomous organization (DAO) called [Yield Guild Games](https://yieldguild.io/) which leases Axies to players that want to get started with the game but don’t have the funds to purchase them. Several rare Axies were even [purchased](https://www.delphidigital.io/reports/why-we-spent-159k-on-digital-battle-pets-2/) for $159,000 total.

\
 ![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/26353bcc-0d05-47ea-89ac-fcdc9d2dd848.jpeg)

\
There’s another popular game [Dark Forest](https://zkga.me/) where you can explore different planets and collect Artifact NFTs on new planets, which give bonuses when attached to the planet. Being able to discover and collect these items or even win them in a battle and then trade them in decentralized marketplaces can make the game even more fun.

\
 ![Planet in Dark Forest which has an Artifact NFT](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/be66b61a-05f0-46b7-aa8f-f7ed542d5cd3.jpeg)

\
One concern with making in-game items tradable is that the ability to trade items can negatively affect the gameplay as people are focused on extracting value from the system or only the players that are willing to pay a lot of money for items can enjoy the game. Diablo III had an auction house where users could trade in-game items for in-game currency and cash. It was [shut down](https://www.wired.com/2013/09/diablo-auction-house/) because of how it affected the game. It was no longer fun and rewarding since players would just buy the best loot. In Diablo III, having the best loot was essentially the goal of the game so having an auction house severely affected gameplay whereas other games are not set up this way. It’s important for game developers to find a balance on what should be freely traded for their game (e.g. skins rather than weapons, [game time](https://secure.eveonline.com/plex/) itself can be traded, etc).

#### Social tokens

The emerging area of social tokens grew significantly in 2020. Social tokens are a broad category of tokens issued by individuals and communities. This term encompasses other similar terms like personal token, community token, and creator token. So far there hasn’t been a standardized term but I will use social tokens to refer to the broader category. Social tokens enable creators and communities to have more ownership in what they are building which is extremely exciting.

\
 ![Social tokens map created by Forefront and Seedclub in ](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/b9316db6-25dd-4c4e-bbb2-b18cfa9a7890.jpeg)

\
Early experiments of social tokens involved people tokenizing their time. For example [Reuben Bramanathan](https://twitter.com/bramanathan?lang=en), who previously worked on legal and product at Coinbase, tokenized his time where 1 [$CSNL](https://www.bramanathan.com/) token equaled 1 hour of his time and was freely traded. We also saw people attempting to tokenize part of their future income. Platforms like [Roll](https://tryroll.com/) and [Coinvise](https://coinvise.co/) make it easier for people to issue their own token.

One prominent example of a social token is [$RAC](https://blog.ourzora.com/home/introducing-rac), a community token by the Grammy award winning recording artist [RAC](https://twitter.com/RAC), issued through Zora. Token holders get access to a private Discord group and receive early access to merch drops with more perks to be added in the future. The token was retroactively distributed to his supporters including Bandcamp and Patreon supporters, people who had bought merch, and will eventually be distributed to all Twitch supporters. This allows creators to directly interact with and reward their early supporters.

One of the tools that enabled a new wave of social tokens was [Collab.Land](https://collab.land/), which built a Telegram and Discord bot that connects to an Ethereum wallet to verify token balance before joining a chat group. This allowed for the creation of token permissioned groups, such as [$JAMM](https://www.jammpad.com/) and [$KARMA](https://andrwlee.medium.com/announcing-karma-dao-first-ever-token-permissioned-networking-chat-group-on-telegram-5feab7a54def) with their native tokens, which helped make sure that those joining the group had a certain level of skin in the game. Another feature of Collab.Land is a leaderboard that keeps track of who has contributed the most to the chat group. You could imagine token rewards distributed to those with the highest amounts of participation to reward engagement.

Another useful social token tool is [Unite Community](https://unite.community/) which allows for creators to easily distribute their tokens to followers through their social media channels and reward engagement.

\
 ![Unite.community distribution](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/0026c774-c91d-443f-a295-161236ad0fba.jpeg)

\
The interesting part about social tokens is that it can represent anything from a person’s time to specialized access to collective ownership of a community. There is a lot of potential for social tokens and I expect many more creators to issue them in the future.

#### Future

These are just a few of the many use cases that are possible and have gotten some traction. There will likely be a significant increase in NFT adoption over the next several years. Traditional assets like equity getting tokenized seems like a clear progression in the future as it would make transferring them far more efficient. Then we’ll see tokenization that bridges the traditional world but adds new possibilities such as advertising space represented as an NFT where you could sell advertising rights to a site and have that be freely tradable. This would be a form of digital real estate. These NFTs would allow people to bet that a website will get a lot of traction and that the advertising space will become more valuable. Then we’ll start seeing more tokens with brand new concepts that are only made possible because of crypto which is what I’m most excited about.

\
 ![Table from Will Warren’s presentation at ](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/d8459ba6-156e-48a1-86ad-4182988bfdfc.jpeg)

\
There are a few aspects of the user experience that need to be improved in order for NFTs to become more accessible. We need to have improvements to scaling since transaction fees can make some transactions very expensive or infeasible. Scaling research is already in the works with many different teams in Ethereum working on scaling solutions and we also are seeing other blockchains being built that are catered specifically for this use case. Another point of friction with NFTs is that holders will need to self-custody them. However this complexity can be abstracted away with user friendly wallets that make it easy to onboard and support features such as a PIN, biometrics, and social account recovery. I’m optimistic that these will get built out over time and we will see a huge wave of creativity and experimentation in the NFT space.

#### Resources

Here are some additional resources to understand NFTs further and keep up with developments.

Understanding NFTs

* [Quick Overview of the NFT Ecosystem](https://andrewsteinwold.substack.com/p/-quick-overview-of-the-nft-ecosystem) by Andrew Steinwold
* [The Non-Fungible Token Bible](https://opensea.io/blog/guides/non-fungible-tokens/) by Devin Finzer
* [Social Tokens Year in Review](https://2020inreview.forefront.news/) by Cooper Turley

Keeping up with NFTs

* [DeFi Arts Intelligencer newsletter](https://artsdefi.substack.com/) by William Peaster
* [Zima Red newsletter](https://andrewsteinwold.substack.com/) by Andrew Steinwold
* [Forefront newsletter](https://forefront.market/) on social tokens

If you want to get in touch about interesting NFT ideas or projects, I’m [@ljxie](https://twitter.com/ljxie) on Twitter.

Thanks to [Will Warren](https://twitter.com/willwarren89) and [Jordan Clifford](https://twitter.com/jcliff42) for reviewing this post.

*Disclaimer: Linda Xie is a Managing Director of Scalar Capital Management, LLC, an investment manager focused on cryptoassets which holds ETH and Ethereum tokens. This post is not investment advice.*

[Gods Unchained](https://godsunchained.com/) and [SkyWeaver](https://www.skyweaver.net/) are two trading card games (TCGs) that have cards that are freely tradable. You are also able to earn cards as you level up in the game. Players that did not purchase packs of cards will still be able to improve upon the game’s default decks. It’s an exciting feeling knowing that the earned cards have real world value and can be sold or traded for other cards. Gods Unchained also lets users earn tokens for when they win a match or refer their friend. The tokens themselves unlock rare in-game items and are also freely tradable.

\
 ![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/aa82c586-39b6-46b1-ae55-cb8a2e44c8e1.jpeg)

\
One of the most popular games in crypto is [Axie Infinity](https://axieinfinity.com/). You battle with a team of pet Axies and level them up. There's no aspect of the gameplay that feels like a blockchain game but there is the added benefit of being able to openly trade the Axies on NFT marketplaces such as [OpenSea](https://opensea.io/). The game has become popular in the [Philippines](https://www.coindesk.com/nft-game-filipinos-covid) and earning tokens from the game has become a viable source of income for players even [beating minimum wage](https://www.playtoearn.online/2020/07/08/axie-infinity-beats-minimum-wage-in-many-countries/) in many countries. There is also a decentralized autonomous organization (DAO) called [Yield Guild Games](https://yieldguild.io/) which leases Axies to players that want to get started with the game but don’t have the funds to purchase them. Several rare Axies were even [purchased](https://www.delphidigital.io/reports/why-we-spent-159k-on-digital-battle-pets-2/) for $159,000 total.

\
 ![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/26353bcc-0d05-47ea-89ac-fcdc9d2dd848.jpeg)

\
There’s another popular game [Dark Forest](https://zkga.me/) where you can explore different planets and collect Artifact NFTs on new planets, which give bonuses when attached to the planet. Being able to discover and collect these items or even win them in a battle and then trade them in decentralized marketplaces can make the game even more fun.

\
 ![Planet in Dark Forest which has an Artifact NFT](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/be66b61a-05f0-46b7-aa8f-f7ed542d5cd3.jpeg)

\
One concern with making in-game items tradable is that the ability to trade items can negatively affect the gameplay as people are focused on extracting value from the system or only the players that are willing to pay a lot of money for items can enjoy the game. Diablo III had an auction house where users could trade in-game items for in-game currency and cash. It was [shut down](https://www.wired.com/2013/09/diablo-auction-house/) because of how it affected the game. It was no longer fun and rewarding since players would just buy the best loot. In Diablo III, having the best loot was essentially the goal of the game so having an auction house severely affected gameplay whereas other games are not set up this way. It’s important for game developers to find a balance on what should be freely traded for their game (e.g. skins rather than weapons, [game time](https://secure.eveonline.com/plex/) itself can be traded, etc).

#### Social tokens

The emerging area of social tokens grew significantly in 2020. Social tokens are a broad category of tokens issued by individuals and communities. This term encompasses other similar terms like personal token, community token, and creator token. So far there hasn’t been a standardized term but I will use social tokens to refer to the broader category. Social tokens enable creators and communities to have more ownership in what they are building which is extremely exciting.

\
 ![Social tokens map created by Forefront and Seedclub in ](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/b9316db6-25dd-4c4e-bbb2-b18cfa9a7890.jpeg)

\
Early experiments of social tokens involved people tokenizing their time. For example [Reuben Bramanathan](https://twitter.com/bramanathan?lang=en), who previously worked on legal and product at Coinbase, tokenized his time where 1 [$CSNL](https://www.bramanathan.com/) token equaled 1 hour of his time and was freely traded. We also saw people attempting to tokenize part of their future income. Platforms like [Roll](https://tryroll.com/) and [Coinvise](https://coinvise.co/) make it easier for people to issue their own token.

One prominent example of a social token is [$RAC](https://blog.ourzora.com/home/introducing-rac), a community token by the Grammy award winning recording artist [RAC](https://twitter.com/RAC), issued through Zora. Token holders get access to a private Discord group and receive early access to merch drops with more perks to be added in the future. The token was retroactively distributed to his supporters including Bandcamp and Patreon supporters, people who had bought merch, and will eventually be distributed to all Twitch supporters. This allows creators to directly interact with and reward their early supporters.

One of the tools that enabled a new wave of social tokens was [Collab.Land](https://collab.land/), which built a Telegram and Discord bot that connects to an Ethereum wallet to verify token balance before joining a chat group. This allowed for the creation of token permissioned groups, such as [$JAMM](https://www.jammpad.com/) and [$KARMA](https://andrwlee.medium.com/announcing-karma-dao-first-ever-token-permissioned-networking-chat-group-on-telegram-5feab7a54def) with their native tokens, which helped make sure that those joining the group had a certain level of skin in the game. Another feature of Collab.Land is a leaderboard that keeps track of who has contributed the most to the chat group. You could imagine token rewards distributed to those with the highest amounts of participation to reward engagement.

Another useful social token tool is [Unite Community](https://unite.community/) which allows for creators to easily distribute their tokens to followers through their social media channels and reward engagement.

\
 ![Unite.community distribution](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/0026c774-c91d-443f-a295-161236ad0fba.jpeg)

\
The interesting part about social tokens is that it can represent anything from a person’s time to specialized access to collective ownership of a community. There is a lot of potential for social tokens and I expect many more creators to issue them in the future.

#### Future

These are just a few of the many use cases that are possible and have gotten some traction. There will likely be a significant increase in NFT adoption over the next several years. Traditional assets like equity getting tokenized seems like a clear progression in the future as it would make transferring them far more efficient. Then we’ll see tokenization that bridges the traditional world but adds new possibilities such as advertising space represented as an NFT where you could sell advertising rights to a site and have that be freely tradable. This would be a form of digital real estate. These NFTs would allow people to bet that a website will get a lot of traction and that the advertising space will become more valuable. Then we’ll start seeing more tokens with brand new concepts that are only made possible because of crypto which is what I’m most excited about.

\
 ![Table from Will Warren’s presentation at ](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/d8459ba6-156e-48a1-86ad-4182988bfdfc.jpeg)

\
There are a few aspects of the user experience that need to be improved in order for NFTs to become more accessible. We need to have improvements to scaling since transaction fees can make some transactions very expensive or infeasible. Scaling research is already in the works with many different teams in Ethereum working on scaling solutions and we also are seeing other blockchains being built that are catered specifically for this use case. Another point of friction with NFTs is that holders will need to self-custody them. However this complexity can be abstracted away with user friendly wallets that make it easy to onboard and support features such as a PIN, biometrics, and social account recovery. I’m optimistic that these will get built out over time and we will see a huge wave of creativity and experimentation in the NFT space.

#### Resources

Here are some additional resources to understand NFTs further and keep up with developments.

Understanding NFTs

* [Quick Overview of the NFT Ecosystem](https://andrewsteinwold.substack.com/p/-quick-overview-of-the-nft-ecosystem) by Andrew Steinwold
* [The Non-Fungible Token Bible](https://opensea.io/blog/guides/non-fungible-tokens/) by Devin Finzer
* [Social Tokens Year in Review](https://2020inreview.forefront.news/) by Cooper Turley

* [Zima Red newsletter](https://andrewsteinwold.substack.com/) by Andrew Steinwold
* [Forefront newsletter](https://forefront.market/) on social tokens

#### What are NFTs?

Non-fungible token (NFT) is a term used to describe a unique digital asset whose ownership is tracked on a blockchain, such as Ethereum. Assets that can be represented as NFTs range from digital goods, such as items that exist within virtual worlds, to claims on physical assets such as clothing items or real estate. In the coming years, we will see NFTs used to unlock entirely new use cases that are only made possible by crypto.

 ![Test caption](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/9799dae1-c2c9-4712-813b-10b23c279a36.jpeg)

While the Ethereum ecosystem is where most NFT activity has taken place to date, NFTs can exist on other smart contract platforms too. This is because, at their core, NFTs are just digital abstractions used to represent assets that are one of a kind. Non-fungible token isn’t the most intuitive term since we don’t commonly refer to the fungibility of objects in the physical world, but this is an important technical distinction when it comes to how an asset is represented on a blockchain. The goal for this post is not to detail every project within the NFT space, but to give a high level overview of what NFTs are, why they are interesting, and showcase some of their potential use cases.

#### Why are NFTs interesting?

NFTs are powerful because, when combined with other financial building blocks on Ethereum, they allow anyone to issue, own, and trade them. This makes interacting with NFTs significantly more efficient than in traditional platforms. The same reason why cryptocurrency used in payments is more efficient than traditional payments, that it is borderless and significantly easier to transfer, applies to NFTs. For example, if you want to create tradable in-game items as a game developer, then you can instantly have them be tradable through protocols that allow for decentralized exchange of NFTs. You don’t have to create your own marketplace or go through the onboarding process of a centralized platform in order to have the items be tradable.

NFT activity can go well past trading and include actions like being able to borrow and lend, support fractional ownership (e.g. [NIFTEX](https://www.niftex.com/)), or use it as collateral in taking out a loan (e.g. [NFTfi](https://nftfi.com/)). The possibilities are endless when you have the ability to combine NFTs with DeFi building blocks. For example, the game [Aavegotchi](http://aavegotchi.com) combines DeFi and NFT gaming where each Aavegotchi character represents a user’s collateral that is deposited within the lending platform [Aave](https://aave.com/), but you can also battle the characters, level them up, and equip wearables that change their traits.

\
 ![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/a1259686-6b61-455a-a204-f6e6da648f10.jpeg)

\
NFTs can cover an extremely wide variety of areas given they are simply digital representations of ownership but there has been significant growth within art and gaming in particular. Note that many digital works of art and gaming items are a subset of a larger category of NFT collectibles. There is also the emerging space of social tokens, which sometimes falls into the NFT category or that is closely related to it.

#### Art

NFTs can make fractionalized ownership more accessible, so if there is a valuable item that otherwise wouldn’t have been accessible for someone to own, now they can own a piece of it. Custody of a physical item still requires a trustworthy custodian, but being able to issue, hold, and trade it as a cryptoasset unlocks more use cases. One can also craft an NFT such that the creator receives a percentage of all secondary sales in a completely automated way. Artists typically don’t receive a cut of secondary sales in the traditional art world.

Programmable art is another interesting concept where a piece of artwork can incorporate on-chain data to dynamically update certain features or characteristics of the work. For example, one could create a piece of programmable art whose background changes if the price of ether goes above a certain dollar-value. There are countless creative possibilities.

\
 ![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/a51670c0-4a1c-4aaf-917d-0e551855b56d.jpeg)

\
[Async Art](https://async.art/) is a digital art marketplace known for programmable art. Many artists on Async sell artwork where someone is able to own the “master” copy which consists of a number of individual layers, but other people can own the individual layers and adjust their attributes over time. Imagine groups of people being able to own art collectively, where members of the group manage attributes of the work.

\
 ![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/fea07c75-8b3c-4592-b8f2-f5d6d92e544c.jpeg)

\
A common question about digital artwork is what can you do with it? These works can be displayed in digital frames in a physical setting for people to enjoy. The digital artist Beeple sold physical tokens along with his digital NFTs and made [$3.5 million](https://niftygateway.com/itemdetail/primary/0x6e5dc5405baefb8c0166bcc78d2692777f2cbffb/21) from sales in an auction on the Nifty Gateway marketplace.

\
 ![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/8689be31-b33f-46ac-94aa-feea3a1b3dd1.jpeg)

\
Digital artwork can also be displayed in online collections like a [SuperRare profile](https://superrare.co/thevault/collection) as well as in virtual worlds. There are a number of art galleries within [Cryptovoxels](http://cryptovoxels.com), a virtual world where users can buy and sell land parcels as NFTs. As virtual reality spaces become more popular, having digital art to display will become more common. This wouldn’t be much different than someone spending money on video game items to customize a character’s appearance, already a multi-billion dollar industry.

\
 ![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/7386d358-d43d-4934-9ea5-b51c33932365.jpeg)

A common skepticism is that someone can just take a screenshot of the image or get a digital file so it’s not really scarce. However, the same argument could apply to physical items as well. Anyone can take a photo of the Mona Lisa or create a replica of it, but it isn’t the real item from the artist. People are willing to pay a premium for the original work. Another interesting aspect of digital art or collectibles is that you can easily verify the item’s ownership history. Some digital items might be worth more depending on who owned it in the past.

With NFTs, you can also prove that the item is real and tamper proof. This is an issue in the physical collectibles space. \
 ![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/26353bcc-0d05-47ea-89ac-fcdc9d2dd848.jpeg)

\
There’s another popular game [Dark Forest](https://zkga.me/) where you can explore different planets and collect Artifact NFTs on new planets, which give bonuses when attached to the planet. title: Use Polygon for the first time
body:
## What is Polygon?
Polygon consists of two major components. Polygon Framework and Polygon Protocol. The polygon framework allows developers to spin up their own blockchain network that offers the same developer experience and security as Ethereum while also providing the scalability and flexibility of stand-alone blockchains. The Polygon Protocol provides the method of connecting two different Polygon Chains and the Ethereum Main Chain.

Polygon lowers entry barriers by reducing the transaction costs to an absolute minimum by taking a multi-prong approach to scaling. Protocols like Curve, Aave, Balancer, and Sushiswap have already launched on Polygon. The low transaction costs and fast transaction speeds have encouraged game developers to launch on Polygon. Zed.Run and Aavegotchi are two such games.

## Setting up a Custom Wallet RPC

- Open the Metamask extension on your browser and select the dropdown at the top where it says “Ethereum Mainnet.”

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/8c85570b-e9f4-4d5f-b0aa-bc4fa7c31050.png?height=124&width=694)

- Select the “Custom RPC” option, and you’ll see this form. 

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/6652d2e2-4dcd-4f8f-8fe7-a4f7930094ed.png?height=1066&width=718)

- Enter the following information in the respective fields

    - Network Name: Polygon
    - New RPC URL: https://rpc-mainnet.matic.network/
    - Chain ID: 137
    - Currency Symbol: MATIC
    - Block Explorer URL: https://polygonscan.com/

- Click “Save”

The Matic Network Documentation linked [here](https://docs.matic.network/docs/develop/network-details/network/) contains a list of other RPCs that you can use. 

## Bridging Funds from the Ethereum Mainnet to Polygon (Using Zapper.fi)

- Go to https://zapper.fi/ and connect your MetaMask wallet.
Once connected, select ‘Bridge’ from the sidebar.
